title: Building Systems and Leading Teams - Bri from SmartLogic

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: Today I'm joined by Bree, the COO at SmartLogic. Bree's path isn't cookie cutter. A former educator, who found herself in tech leadership, building systems, teams, and products that actually ship. We covered two big points. First, why educators thrive in tech. how creating lesson plans can become roadmaps, classroom metrics become KPIs, Second, how to communicate cross technical lines. Active listening, back summaries, and ruthless documentation So a junior developer can pick up a system months after without any guesswork. Listen and you'll leave with one practical plan, the 30 day AI Tiger mission. Pick one legacy app to find a narrow modernization target. Use AI to accelerate codes, documentation, and testing. Keep a developer in the loop for architecture and security and publish the lessons learned back to the team. which nets in faster maintenance, safer releases, and a culture that stays current without burning billable hours. Let's dive in.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: Hey, Bree, welcome to the show. Do you mind introducing yourself?

transcript.speaker: Bri Bellavati
transcript.text: Thank you, Brian. Hi, everyone. My name is Bri Belavati. I am Chief Operating Officer at SmartLogic.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: Tell me about your background that led you to SmartLogic.

transcript.speaker: Bri Bellavati
transcript.text: It's not traditional or conventional in any sense of the definition. My roots started off in education. I was a high school English teacher in Ocean City, Maryland. From there as a high school vice principal, moved like life does to Western Maryland and became a dean at a community and technical college. From there, I really started working a lot more with private industry because I was on the workforce side of things, which is like the short-term training. So working a lot with industry. IT, welding, advanced manufacturing, economic development, really kind of working on how can the college meet the needs of the workforce and how we can best prepare them. From there, I got a call out of the blue from a gentleman who owns a custom dev shop. And he goes, hey, Bri, I want you to come work for me. And I'm like, Jason, don't you do something with computers? And he goes, yeah. I was like, again, I was an English teacher and you are a. computer guy, like we were on opposite sides of the school. What do you possibly, what could I possibly do for you? And he said, well, that's the thing. And a respectful way I say this, he goes, it's just really me and the geeks. And he goes, I've got developers and design and it's just me leaving at the helm and I want to grow and I don't have anyone with your kind of skillset. So I'm sitting here going, hmm, do I abandon my education career? I was almost finished with my doctorate at that time in education thinking I was going, you know, college president, deanship, all that jazz. And I was like, all right, let's do it. Now, selfishly, I cut my commute from an hour and a half to four minutes. So like, you know, this is worth an experimentation. Let's see, let's see what I can do. So for him, I started off in training and development just to kind of get acclimated, really understand what are you building and what the needs, what the clients are, what their needs are. And then from there helped grow account management, project management. I shifted into biz dev and that was super fun. I did have a quick pivot. After that role, I helped open the first woman-owned, minority-owned clinical laboratory, March 2020. Nobody remembers what that timeframe was. And so that was a COVID lab. Helped build that company from scratch. And so building systems and processes and structures was my jam, kind of really painting a blank canvas, and that was fun. And then went back to IT leadership, and that's kind of where I am right now. So not traditional at all.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: No, not at all. What are some of the key things that you learned from being a teacher, from working in academia, and how does that translate to now working in tech and being able to like, it sounds like you really worked your way up in the organization at SmartLogic to kind of fulfill a lot of different steps, but like,

transcript.speaker: Bri Bellavati
transcript.text: Mmm. in

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: Is there a certain skill set that teachers or people in academia possess that make them more adapt to kind of fulfill some of these roles?

transcript.speaker: Bri Bellavati
transcript.text: Hmm. excellent question. And my big statement is, yes, your skills are super transferable. So if you're an educator and you're looking like, what else can I do? Tech might be for you 100%. I will say the multitasking as a teacher, teaching a sea of children, most definitely that is part of the job. But it's also thinking as an educator when you are thinking about your year, your curriculum, your unit, your chapter, and like, is it that I want my students to be able to do? And how do you back map? How do you scaffold those learning processes, those steps? Well, that's strategic planning. You know, that's that's planning a backlog that's going from we need this product to do this. How do I start? Where do I start? You know, those that skill of being able to sequentially think through how do get from point A to point B? But I know I want to get to Z. most definitely as an educator skill set. And then if you layer in, mean, my goodness, I wasn't teaching them many years ago, but at that time, data driving decision-making was kind of newer in the field. Well, everything you do in tech is driven by data and structure and being able to look at metrics to make sure, it performing? Is it secure? Is it X, Y, Z? And so most definitely, I think there's a lot of skills that educators just possess to teach. And it doesn't even matter what field you're in, but a really easy way to get into it is in project management, product management. you really, you know, product management, you're thinking about the customers, the consumer, what's going to make them want to engage. Well, that's the same thing as how do you get 15 year old boys to want to, you know, quote Shakespeare? It's a tough challenge. So how do you, what kind of appeal do you need to make it user friendly and approachable? Similar kinds of concepts, similar transferability.

transcript.text: I know that working with technical people comes with its own inherent set of challenges. From a communication perspective, how do you overcome that?

transcript.speaker: Bri Bellavati
transcript.text: I think the root of it is listening, being an active listener. And, you know, When I first started off in training and development and then moved to kind of project management and you are truly that intermediary, that liaison between the client and the devs and kind of how do I play both sides of that fiddle? And I think it's really an act of listening and also asking clarifying questions. I have no shame going, what does that mean? Or, hey, can I tell you what I heard? I am track. If I'm talking to a staff engineer and they say something extremely technical and I try to like summarize it in my own words, because my job would then to be making sure I can communicate that to the client or answer their questions or be able to know how to filter their questions to know which part of our team needs to address that. And so if you don't listen and you also don't check for your comprehension, I think there's nothing embarrassing going, okay. I have not a clue what you just said or why that's important or what the impact could be. Can you help talk me through that? And every single developer, designer, anyone in the technical field that I have asked those questions, they go, hey, thanks for asking, actually. Let me try to explain that to you. Or let me explain why that would matter to the client or what you need to be saying from an account management perspective. so, I mean, it's just being, I think, intentional with your communication of going, what am I here for? And not being superficial. playing the gopher of here's a message, here's a message. But if you really want it to be, I don't know, meaningful and relevant, you've got to engage and you've got to make sure you're saying the right thing. And so ask those questions too.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: It's funny, right? I've been in so many large kickoff meetings where there's been so many assumptions made that when I do a lot of things with self-deprecating humor, where it's like, okay, I may be the dumb one in the room, but can we take a step back and can you explain to me what you're trying to say here? transcript.text: He

So I always like to do that gut check of, okay, if you're a junior developer, you just got onboarded and you're reading this document, does this explain it enough for you to take the next action or to understand the architecture or to understand the connections and whatnot? title: Database Performance and Cloud Costs - Douglas from Fortified

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: On today's episode of Curve Ahead, COO of Fortified, the world of databases, performance what we would bundle up and call observability of phenops. We get into two big ideas. First, Douglas breaks down why cloud billing is exploding and it's not just storage. It's inefficient code, legacy decisions, and the fact that most companies have no real handle on the actual cost of their database queries. He walks through how workload telemetry that drives 80 to 90 % of your infrastructure costs. Second, we zoom out and talk about remote work. run remote first teams long before it was trendy, and he's blunt about what we've lost. Real mentorship. shoulder to shoulder problem solving and that in-person culture that actually sharpens people instead of isolates them. In listening to this episode, you'll walk away with a different lens of performance, not just is it fast, but is the juice worth the squeeze for what we're paying? Let's dive in.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: Hey Douglas, welcome to the show. Do you mind introducing yourself?

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: Sure. Douglas McDowell. And do you want the full rundown? How much introduction do you want,

And it's all the precursors to everything that gets lumped into AI now and did that from a professional services standpoint and did a lot of managed services as well. And then moved into software in beginning of 2017 and was very focused on database performance monitoring and You know, of course, everything monitoring has now become observability, it seems like. And I was with the company Sentry One, Sentry with an S. Not to be confused with Sentry 21 or Sentry the safe company, but Sentry One, because we were a Sentry patrol that watched your database. And we got acquired by SolarWinds at the end of 2020. It's another company that has funny name. SolarWinds doesn't do solar technology, doesn't have any renewable energy. It's another software company. ⁓ worked with SolarWinds and a few stops along the train there. And I'm at Fortified now, doing a lot of the same things because I'm focused on database performance monitoring, observability, and now FinOps. So that was a long way around the box. Brian to tell you one of the things that really attracted me to Fortified is not just getting to do some of the things that I've been doing for a long time and have a passion about, but one of the more recent passions is around the cost of technology. total cost of ownership, the cost of the cloud, but then all up cost of technology. And that's one of the things that I'm getting to work on now that turn me into fortified. I guess I'm supposed to say, and I skipped it, that the people were the reason I came to 452, and I should say that because that's one of the most important things, regardless of what type of technology is exciting and I'm passionate about, but it's all about who you get to do it with. And I'd be remiss not to point that out, and that's a critical part of the draw.

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: It is, yeah. you regardless of whether we want to talk about it or not, but before I was in technology, I was actually in restaurants and hospitality. And so it's always been important.

transcript.text: Yeah, it's funny. transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: So tell me more about what Fortified focuses on. So you were telling me about DB performance, monitoring observability, but also cost of technology, total cost of ownership. What else are you guys focused on? Who are you working with? And just kind of give me that 15,000 foot overview.

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: Yeah, we'll look. Yeah, well, I like the fact that you kind of threw in the 15,000 feet because kind of a level or two above that is this growing issue is that over a decade ago is, you know, the cloud came around much before that, but about a decade ago or so people really started to make that mass migration and really turn up the heat to kind of go to the cloud and everybody, there started to be this groundswell, just people being pissed off about their cloud bill. And, uh, but the thing was, is that there was a shift and, you know, I don't want to get into finance too much, but you probably have heard of capital expenditures and operational expenditures, capital expenditures. We pay for something upfront. Um, and, uh, or operational expenditures, kind of you rent it and The cloud, because it's on a consumption model, was built around operational expenditures or OPEX. And so you didn't really have to plan. You could do infrastructure as code. You could just turn it on. We've even gotten to ephemeral workloads now. But the reality is, is that people were making these critical architectural decisions and spinning up stuff. And holy cow, they find out a month or a quarter ⁓ later about how much they actually spent. Or make mistakes about leaving things on that were supposed to be turned off and all the things that we've heard horror stories about and so when you look at the performance of systems the metrics actually have changed because it's I like to use Metaphors like is the juice worth worth the squeeze, you know if we're going to have ⁓ Guaranteed uptime and have a certain amount of infrastructure to assure business continuity or failover, or if we're going to have a certain amount of sub-second response time on all of our application pages, or whatever the use case is, there's pieces of technology back behind that. There's infrastructure, and there's a heightened cost for that. And of course, developers get really excited about making sure that their applications are fully available and that they're really fast. is the juice worth the squeeze. And so that has really created this issue of the cost of technology. we really have to, whether you're in the cloud or not, we're in an operational expense or OPEX world because even if you're still bare metal running it on prem, most of your stuff, your servers are leased, your software is subscribed to. And so it's all not capital expenses, you're actually running a consumption model in-house. And so kind of setting the table because it's not all about how fast a database or other part of your tech stack performs, it's how fast it performs for what you're paying and are you making good decisions. The other thing is that We never really think about it if we're we the royal week, you know, for developers, we don't think about is there an expiration date on code because there isn't. And sometimes you'll promote code into production and it'll get ⁓ overwritten and wiped out in the next release. But chances are it will stay out there for quite a while. And of course, if you're a production or CIO type of role where you're keeping your systems online and caring and feeding, you're probably dealing with a lot of legacy systems that might have been around for decades even. And so think about when that code was written and how efficient was it written. so therefore, how long, if there's inefficiencies in it, has it been driving higher? cost than it could if you you That's really one of the core things inside of tech debt. ⁓ you know often tech debt is thought about as just You know kind of how they get certain functionality and they build it on top of one another and it's a you know, one thing on top of another that way, but it's also the underlying use of infrastructure and how efficient that is, and that's the can that gets kicked down the road more often than not because historically, you we threw CPUs at it, we threw extra RAM at it, and we threw extra SAN arrays and other storage and... And guess what? It fixed it that year and it was cheaper that year than the man hours or whatever the effort would have been. But now we're 15 years down the road and you're still running that much extra horsepower. Anyway, you get the idea that I can talk about this for a long time. The real question at the beginning, and sorry, I'll land the plane here. ⁓ The real question at the beginning was what Fortified's doing about it.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: haha

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: We're focused on database and the reason we are is, well, number one, that's what we love and we know. But number two is that that's usually your most expensive kind of critical mass workload in the tech stack. It uses the most storage. Well, firstly is that every application is a database application. It has to have a place for the data to live. So it has to be stored, it has to be updated, it has to be deleted. If not needed anymore, of course, data hardly ever gets actually deleted. It's still kept five different places. But anyway, it drives the most, you know, resource utilization. So that's why we're focused on it. But then we're using monitoring or observability information to that historically was all about performance. How do we make it faster? And we're taking that and we're saying, well, actually we have the actual workload information so we can look inside that workload and say, what is the cost of inefficient code all the way down to the query level? Because usually what happens is about 10 to 20 % of all your code, usually about 10 % of it will drive about 80 to 90 % of your overall resource utilization, therefore your cost. And so we can be really prescriptive in saying, These lines of code are, you if you want your bang for the buck to really increase, that's where you need to focus, not on the whole database, not on the whole server.

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: When do you typically see clients coming to you? Is it, hey, you know, I just got my AWS bill and it's insane. transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: Yeah, well, the interesting thing is that we're finding that despite the... When people have a conversation and hear some of the things I was just saying, they kind of walk away. But then there's this other big sphere that is performance because that actually goes all the way to the end user of the applications and what is their performance experience with it. And so that's usually the litmus of whether the database is doing well. And so most people are coming to us to say, we've got performance issues or we have availability. We want visibility around availability and security. And then we really need to do optimization for performance. And then by the time they become a fortified customer, they're all in on. the cost of their database. transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: So one of the things that you had mentioned, and I think this is very timely, is with regards to uptime and security. over the last couple of weeks, it's been wild with both an AWS outage last week and Azure, I think, earlier this week. those are two, one of the two biggest providers out there right now, name-wise. What are your thoughts on that?

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: Well, sure, I think that it just proves out that there's no such thing as bulletproof uptime. regardless of whether you're doing it in-house with good oversight, you're going with some type of semi-private cloud or data center, or you're going with one of the big boys, it's not an if, it's a when on the outage. And you just need to... Be honest with yourself about what your tolerance is for those types of outages because you can, it starts to get really expensive really quick when you say, okay, I can't afford to have all my eggs in one basket, so to speak. But then what does architecting multi-geo failover type of application look like? And again, is the juice worth the squeeze? Sometimes it really is. And it has to be that way. More times than not, it probably doesn't. And people just haven't really talked through. And that's where the whole practice of FinOps comes in, because the first thing that you do in FinOps is that you gain visibility. And then you actually put costing on things and do what's called showback, where you show the actual cost of different things. kind of one of the cliches in the database space and what we deal with is that people don't want to throw their data away. And, you know, like for instance, I don't know, there's a use case where you need to keep it around for seven years, but then it doesn't matter that it's over seven years old. No, it might be valuable. You go, it might be, it costs you $50,000 a year. Oh, oh, well, we can get rid of that. you know, or whatever it is, we've had those conversations because all of a sudden there's a newfound visibility to it. transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
transcript.text: Is that like the cost of storage? Is that one of the biggest surprises that a lot of businesses in executive experience when you're doing that showback process?

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: Well, it's never just the cost of storage it's ⁓ so there's always the consideration of how hot the storage needs to be from a performance and accessibility standpoint. It's storage in some type of database that's online, but then has vulnerabilities to it and has compute attached to it and memory attached to it. you know, all of the patching and everything, the ecosystem that surrounds it. So there's a loaded cost to it. And so it's usually not just the storage costs that's because storage has gotten pretty commoditized and especially if it's kind of mid range or down. So it's everything else. It's the whole, whole package there.

transcript.speaker: Douglas McDowell
transcript.text: Yeah, it's all online. No, no, no, it's true is that you're paying for the consumption of digital and online services. It's about being sticky and being addictive. it's the land and expand motion. And a lot of that comes down to operational ownership tools and operational costs. And that's the other thing that's kind of interesting is that we can help people minimize their cloud spend, get it under control, have more visibility to it. but it actually makes us a friend to like for instance, Microsoft Azure, because people are mad about their cloud bill. And what are people doing? They're constantly shopping clouds and they're constantly moving stuff around. And like one of the things that we focus on is SQL Server. And even though that's a Microsoft technology, it is one of the most portable workloads that runs really well, no matter where it is. AWS RDS, Relational Data Services, which is their platform as a service or PaaS offering for SQL Server, has been benchmarked to be faster than Azure's offering at different times. people, just because they're running on SQL doesn't mean that they're going to run it on Azure. And so Microsoft likes our ability to, if they can keep it in control and feel like ⁓ they can have it in control, they're going to... Data begets data. transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles

transcript.speaker: Brian Wiles
